basics.name: Carlos Gonzalez
basics.label: Ph.D. Candidate
basics.summary: Ph.D. Candidate specializing in dynamic whole-body motion planning and control for humanoid and complex legged systems. Expertise includes Numerical Optimization methods, Model Predictive Control, and software-hardware integration, driven to deploy safe and reliable robotic platforms.
basics.relocation: Willing to relocate nationally and internationally

work.name: Graduate Research Assistant, University of Texas at Austin
work.summary: Doctoral research focused on locomotion and multi-contact planning for humanoid robots navigating confined spaces.
highlights: Developed and benchmarked fast, collision-free multi-contact planning algorithms for humanoids.
Configured, tested, and integrated COTS servo controllers (EtherCAT) into existing hardware.
Developed approach for online optimal horizon selection in Model Predictive Control (MPC).
Designed and prototyped mechanical structure of person-carrying omniwheel mobile robot.
Developed and open-sourced low-level code for EtherCAT devices with ROS integration.

work.name: Institute for Human & Machine Cognition
work.summary: Contributed to software development for legged platforms: Atlas, Quix, and Nadia.
highlights: Designed and implemented (in Java) push recovery and balance strategies on Atlas humanoid.
Improved force sensing and control capabilities of exoskeleton Quix.
Wrote software integration for motor control via CAN for exoskeleton Eva and humanoid Nadia.

work.name: Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia
work.summary: Implemented and validated dynamic balance and motion control strategies on the torque-controlled HyQ quadruped robot.
highlights: Simulated a novel balance control strategy enabling HyQ to balance on two point feet in Gazebo.
Implemented the controller on the real HyQ robot, achieving balance on a support line.
Incorporated motion controller to achieve line walking in simulation.
Submitted and presented main simulations and experimental results in IROS.

work.name: Research Assistant, New York University
work.summary: Conducted sensitivity analysis on the balance-stability of legged systems to quantify design and control trade-offs.
highlights: Designed a computational approach combining numerical optimization and motion planning to establish balance-stability.
Derived quasi-analytical solutions to quantify changes in balance-stability based on design constraints (e.g., torque limits).

work.name: Research Assistant, University of New Mexico
work.summary: Research focused on hybrid system identification methods for prognosis of Parkinson’s Disease.
highlights: Implemented and compared several state-of-the-art methods in hybrid system identification.
Derived an alternate identification approach using optimization methods, achieving more accurate and precise detection of submovements.

work.name: Research Student, University of New Mexico
work.summary: Conducted initial control research for a smart microelectromechanical material used as a microgripper.
highlights: Designed and presented a research proposal plan to academic advisor.
Designed and performed experiments to validate the proposed approach.

volunteer.summary: Assisted in open house event for non-profit providing educational programs for Latinas.
Processed experimental data using Cortex for a study on energy expenditure in human walking.

volunteer.organization: Multi-Agent, Robotic, Hybrid, and Embedded Systems Lab (UNM)
volunteer.summary: Contributed to robotics research by designing, building, and programming hardware.
highlights: Designed and built mechanical parts for quadrotors used for research.
Worked with a 7 DoF robotic arm using MATLAB and its Robotic Toolbox by Peter Corke.
